items.hed: The Best Dressed of the Cannes Film Festival
items.dek: The most talented and strikingly beautiful have gathered in the South of France for the Cannes Film Festival. Lupita floated down the red carpet in Gucci in a swirl of emerald green, Zoë Kravitz was a dream in Valentino, Charlize Theron looked ravishing in a rich-yellow Dior gown, and Emma Stone was captivating in Oscar de la Renta. Check back in as we continue to round up the best dressed of the Cannes Film Festival.

Kate Middleton’s Mother Advocates for Bouncy Castles in New Advice Column
Peggy and Stan’s *Mad Men* Romance Was Hinted at Way Sooner Than We Thought
items.dek: Jay R. Ferguson shipped them before anyone else did.
items.body:
The potential of a romance between Stan Rizzo and Peggy Olson on *Mad Men* had become clear enough in the final few episodes that many of us started rooting for them to get together—even if we [firmly believed]( https://twitter.com/jowrotethis/status/592771467730878464) the show would never be kind enough to actually let it happen. But maybe the reason we were so invested in their relationship was because the seeds had been sown many, many years ago—without creator __Matthew Weiner__ actually intending it. 

Talking to [*The Wall Street Journal*]( http://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2015/05/18/mad-men-jay-ferguson-on-stans-surprising-confession/) and finally free of *Mad Men*’s ironclad confidentiality agreements, __Jay R. Ferguson,__ who played Stan, says that Weiner gave him a firm “no” when he asked if Stan and Peggy would ever get together . . . but Ferguson wasn’t really willing to take that as an answer. “Every chance I got I would always try to put in a little nuance—a look or an intention in a word—to leave that door open on the stuff they gave me with Lizzie. I was trying to pull my own secret coup.” And though Ferguson credits the show’s writers for talking Weiner into giving Stan and Peggy their happy ending sometime during Season 6, he also says, “I like to believe that in some tiny way I helped it come to pass.”

Though the moment, in the way of so many on-screen love scenes, wasn’t quite as romantic in real life as it seemed on the show. “Poor Lizzie, it’s such a great moment for her but you can barely see it because of all the hair that is on my head,” Ferguson said about __Elisabeth Moss.__ “Lizzie was unfortunately picking beard hairs out of her mouth for months.”

Was her sacrifice worth it for the thrill of seeing this happen? Come on, of course it was. 


[#image: /photos/555b4858b80bcc99383a9bee]||||||



[#gallery: /galleries/552ea496fd1bd16507197a94]||||||

items.hed: Watch Anna Kendrick Poke Fun at the All-Female Reboot Trend with Indiana Jones Sketch
items.body:
[#iframe: //player.theplatform.com/p/NnzsPC/widget/select/media/TgV33q6yNHc4](640x390)||||||

First there was the [all-female *Ghostbusters*](http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/01/female-ghostbusters-cast). Then an all-female [*21 Jump Street*](http://www.marieclaire.com/culture/news/a14275/21-jump-street-female-cast/). What’s next? NBC has an answer for you in the form of this *Indiana Jones* sketch starring __Anna Kendrick__ as everyone’s [favorite fedora-wearing adventurer](http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/05/indiana-jones-sequel-confirmed). No, this isn’t a *Saturday Night Live* sketch, it’s a promotion for NBC’s upcoming charity TV event *Red Nose Day*. 

The three-hour show is based on the enormously popular, long-running British version that started way back in 1985 to “bring about positive and lasting change in the lives of poor and disadvantaged people, which we believe requires investing in work that addresses people's immediate needs as well as tackling the root causes of poverty and injustice.” NBC will air the first-ever American version later this month, and the network has recruited an all-star roster including (deep breath) Kendrick, __Julia Roberts, Will Ferrell, Jennifer Aniston, Reese Witherspoon, Julianne Moore, Jodie Foster, Neil Patrick Harris, Christina Aguilera, Pharrell, Adam Levine, Paul Rudd, Benedict Cumberbatch, Eddie Redmayne, Simon Cowell, Richard Gere, Jimmy Fallon, Jennifer Garner, Keith Urban, John Mellencamp, Zac Efron, Helen Mirren, Robert Pattinson, Liam Neeson, Rose Byrne, Nick Cannon, Matt LeBlanc, Hugh Bonneville, Dame Diana Rigg, Kyle MacLachlan, Elisabeth Moss, Hoda Kotb, Gilbert Gottfried, Cheryl Burke, Nicole Scherzinger, Jeff Dye,__ One Direction, and a handful of *Saturday Night Live* cast members. 

The highlight of the evening will surely be a mockumentary sketch about the making of a fictitious *Game of Thrones: The Musical* written by Coldplay and starring a number of the HBO series cast members. Goodness knows we could use something a little upbeat from Westeros. The American *Red Nose Day* airs Thursday, May 21 at eight P.M. 

__WATCH: Anna Kendrick & Natalie Martinez on *End of Watch*__


[#video: //player.cnevids.com/embed/51ccb6f7c2b4c00d584240d9/51cc9f86bb8f554e4e000002](690x388)||||||

items.hed: Why You Won’t Be Reading Hillary Clinton’s E-mails Anytime Soon
items.dek: Except for those from Sidney Blumenthal.
items.body:
The State Department’s review of __Hillary Clinton’s__ e-mails will not be completed until January, meaning reporters and the public will not have access to the approximately 55,000 pages of documents Clinton’s team handed over to the department. 

Clinton came under fire when *The New York Times* revealed that she had exclusively used a personal e-mail address during her time in Foggy Bottom. The server for the e-mail, which used the domain “clintonemail.com,” was located in her personal residence, and the e-mails that Clinton did not elect to turn over to the State Department have been erased. 

In March, when the *Times* [first reported on her use of the personal e-mail address for government business](http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/03/us/politics/hillary-clintons-use-of-private-email-at-state-department-raises-flags.html), the State Department said it was in the process of reviewing the 55,000 pages it received after asking Clinton to hand over any work-related e-mails. That was in March, and [according to a court filing reported on by Vice News](https://news.vice.com/article/state-department-says-clinton-emails-wont-be-released-until-january-2016), the process will not be finished until next year—just two weeks before the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary.

That does not mean, however, that some of Clinton’s e-mails are not already starting to cause her political trouble. Intelligence reports regarding Libya that the then secretary of state received from longtime Clinton ally __Sidney Blumenthal__ [landed in the *Times* today](http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/19/us/politics/clinton-friends-libya-role-blurs-lines-of-politics-and-business.html), suggesting that Clinton maintained a relationship with Blumenthal long after President __Barack Obama’s__ aides had forbid Blumenthal be granted a position at the State Department. 

Blumenthal would send Clinton intelligence reports that drew on his business contacts and others within Libya, and Clinton would often forward them on to her deputy, __Jake Sullivan__, sometimes directing him to distribute the information to other officials within the department. Others at State sometimes met the information with skepticism, and Clinton herself wrote that one of Blumenthal’s e-mails “strains credulity.” (Gawker and ProPublica [first reported the existence of Blumenthal’s e-mails to Clinton](http://gawker.com/leaked-private-emails-reveal-ex-clinton-aides-secret-sp-1694112647); the *Times* revealed that Clinton had indeed read and forwarded some of the messages.)

Blumenthal was working with several Western businessmen seeking contracts from Libya’s transitional government after the killing of Muammar el-Qaddafi. It’s not clear whether Clinton knew of Blumenthal’s business arrangements, none of which seem to have come to fruition. 

In what has become a common thread among the scandals dotting the early months of Clinton’s campaign for the presidency, the Clinton Foundation also plays a part in the mystery. Blumenthal was employed by the foundation, and consulted for American Bridge and Media Matters, two organizations that work to counter Republican attacks on the Clintons. 

__Congressman Trey Gowdy__, a South Carolina Republican leading the investigation of the attacks in Benghazi that killed four Americans, including ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, plans to subpoena Blumenthal. 

Reporters hoping to shed further light on the extent of Blumenthal’s involvement in Clinton’s State Department might be out of luck. Clinton [has only taken approximately 13 questions](http://www.politico.com/story/2015/05/hillary-clinton-2016-press-118073.html) from journalists since declaring her candidacy for president. 

__Update (12:25 P.M.)__: Clinton took some questions from the press today, after Fox News’s __Ed Henry__ asked when she planned on speaking with reporters. On the subject of Blumenthal, Clinton said she plans to continue speaking with her “old friends.”

[#twitter: https://twitter.com/BrentScher/status/600697456070946816]

items.seoDescription: Except for those from Sidney Blumenthal.

fields.name: Vanity Fair
fields.bio: *Vanity Fair* features in-depth reporting, gripping narratives, and world-class photography, plus heaping doses of Oscar-blogging, royal-watching, and assorted guilty pleasures.  Every month,the magazine commissions the best writers and photographers to explain the pressing issues of the day and take the pulse of the culture. Vanity Fair consistently delivers crucial reporting on business and finance, domestic politics and world affairs, even as it covers the very best in arts and entertainment.

items.dek: To accompany Bruce Handy’s profile of *Mad Men* as the AMC series begins is third season, Annie Leibovitz photographed stars Jon Hamm and January Jones, channeling their characters, Don and Betty.

items.caption: Jon Hamm and January Jones, channeling their Mad Men characters. Photographed at the Lightbourne House, in Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas.
items.credit: Photograph by Annie Leibovitz; Styled by Michael Roberts.

items.caption: “A lot of what I do with Betty is in the eyes,” says Jones. “A lot of the feelings are unspoken, so that’s kind of been fun to play with.”
items.credit: Photograph by Annie Leibovitz; Styled by Michael Roberts.

items.caption: Asked about his favorite scenes with Jones, Hamm says, “It’s always fun when we fight. I think January would agree with that.”
items.credit: Photograph by Annie Leibovitz; Styled by Michael Roberts.

items.caption: Hamm “has this wonderful sadness and lost quality in his eyes,” said director Alan Taylor. “It’s a rare quality for a strapping leading man.”
items.credit: Photograph by Annie Leibovitz; Styled by Michael Roberts.

items.caption: “Betty’s whole life is a façade,” says Jones. “If she can’t keep up the pretense everything is perfect, she will crumble and die, I think.”
items.credit: Photograph by Annie Leibovitz; Styled by Michael Roberts.

items.caption: Jones gave “one of the most remarkable auditions I’ve ever seen,” said Matthew Weiner.
items.credit: Photograph by Annie Leibovitz; Styled by Michael Roberts.

fields.name: Annie Leibovitz
fields.bio:
Annie Leibovitz was born on October 2, 1949, in Waterbury, Connecticut. While studying painting at the San Francisco Art Institute, she took night classes in photography, and in 1970 she began doing work for *Rolling Stone* magazine. She became *Rolling Stone*’s chief photographer in 1973. By the time she left the magazine, 10 years later, she had shot 142 covers. In 1983, she joined the staff at *Vanity Fair*, and in 1998 she also began working regularly for *Vogue*. In addition to her magazine editorial work, Leibovitz has created several award-winning advertising campaigns. She has also collaborated with many arts organizations, including American Ballet Theatre, the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and the Mark Morris Dance Group, and with Mikhail Baryshnikov. Her books include *Annie Leibovitz: Photographs* (1983), *Photographs: Annie Leibovitz 1970–1990* (1991), *Olympic Portraits* (1996), *Women* (1999), *American Music* (2003), *A Photographer’s Life: 1990–2005* (2006), *Annie Leibovitz at Work* (2008), *Pilgrimage* (2011), and *Annie Leibovitz*, a limited-edition, over-sized volume published by Taschen in 2014. 

Exhibitions of her photographs have appeared at museums and galleries all over the world, including the National Portrait Gallery and the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington, D.C.; the International Center of Photography in New York; the Brooklyn Museum; the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam; the Maison Européenne de la Photographie in Paris; the National Portrait Gallery in London; and the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia. Leibovitz has been designated a Living Legend by the Library of Congress and is the recipient of many other honors, including a Lifetime Achievement Award from the International Center of Photography, the Centenary Medal of the Royal Photographic Society in London, and the Wexner Prize. She has been decorated a Commandeur in the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres by the French government. Leibovitz lives in New York with her three children, Sarah, Susan, and Samuelle.

items.hed: Turn on Your Adult Content Filters: Miley Cyrus Is Back in Full Miley Mode
items.seoTitle: Miley Cyrus Is Back in Full Miley Mode
items.socialTitle: Turn on Your Adult Content Filters: Miley Cyrus Is Back in Full Miley Mode
items.body:
[#video: //instagram.com/p/2qVXyXQzP_/embed/](612x710)||||||

There was, not too long ago, a time when not a day went by without one—usually more than one!—outrageous, salacious __Miley Cyrus__ headline. And while Cyrus still garners her share of press these days—her Instagram account continues to buoy the tabloid-industrial complex—she has kept a slightly lower profile in recent months, even as her relationship with __Patrick Schwarzenegger__ [came to an end](http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/04/miley-cyrus-and-patrick-schwarzenegger-have-broken-up) in quite public fashion.
 
But now, perhaps preparing for the lead-up to a new album cycle (we’re coming up on two years since the release of her *Bangerz*, after all), Cyrus packed about a month’s worth of “Cyrus gone wild!” items into one evening during her performance at the Adult Swim upfront party in New York last night (Miley Cyrus and Adult Swim is about as good as brand pairings get).
 
Let’s work our way though [everything Miley did last night](http://variety.com/2015/scene/vpage/miley-cyrus-lights-up-adult-swim-party-upfronts-1201495589/), per *Variety*:
 
—  She wore butterfly wings on her back and glitter all over her face.

—  After her first song, she asked, “Where’s my joint?,” before procuring one, telling the crowd she’d “grab a lighter.”

—  She was magnanimous, as far as her . . . rations went, asking the audience, “Are you guys drunk yet? Are you guys high yet? . . . No?! You’re gonna be at a show where I’m dressed as a f–king butterfly and not be high? I’m down to share.” She then passed her blunt into the crowd, warning, “You better pass that back.”

—   She covered songs by Johnny Cash and Led Zeppelin.

—   She [covered](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mo_o7K0iq2A) __Khia’s__ “My Neck, My Back (Lick It).”

—   Oh, she was wearing a sheer top the whole time, exposing her pink nipple pasties and dyed armpit hair.

—   She promoted her foundation, Happy Hippie, and urged the crowd to offer their help, and money, to those less fortunate.

—   She performed part of a new single from her next album, which she said was called “Tiger Dreams” (clips of which are rapidly being taken down from YouTube).
 
And now, this morning, naturally, she has posted [four Instagrams](ttps://instagram.com/mileycyrus/) (and counting—and we really mean “counting” here, since Cyrus has never been accused of taking the “less-is-more” approach, when it comes to her Instagrams) from last night’s festivities.
 
If this is the kind of night Cyrus is having before the promotional cycle for this next album has even begun full-fledged, we can only imagine what sort of shenanigans we have in store for us.
items.seoDescription: Nipple pasties, raunchy song covers, butterfly wings, and more!
items.socialDescription: Nipple pasties, raunchy song covers, butterfly wings, and more!

fields.title: t-miley-cyrus-butterfly-wings.jpg
fields.credit: By Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images for Tuner.

fields.name: Josh Duboff
fields.bio: Josh Duboff is a VF.com staff writer, based in New York, who covers entertainment and culture. He writes an "Imagined Celebrity Connections" column every Friday. He's also the writer/director of a web series, *Twenty Five*. Photo by Justin Bishop.

items.hed: Kate Middleton’s Mother Advocates for Bouncy Castles in New Advice Column
items.seoTitle: Kate Middleton’s Mother Advocates for Bouncy Castles in New Advice Column
items.socialTitle: Kate Middleton’s Mother Advocates for Bouncy Castles in New Advice Column
items.body:
__Carole Middleton__—mother to __Kate__, as well as __Pippa__ and __James__—has maintained a pretty low, if quietly visible, profile over the past few years. Most people are aware of two biographical details when it comes to Carole: one, she (with husband Michael) started an extremely successful party-supplies business, and, secondly . . . well our second one was just going to be that she’s Kate’s mom, again. But, now a grandmother for the second time with the arrival of __Princess Charlotte__, Carole has decided to make a foray into the world of publishing, like [daughter Pippa before her](http://www.vanityfair.com/contributor/pippa-middleton). Carole has just published [her first column](http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20924035,00.html) for *Little London* magazine (she has also been made a contributing editor), which centers on, you guessed it, parties. In particular, Carole is offering us pointers on how to throw a smashing, to use a word Carole might employ, children’s birthday party.
 
“We’ve always believed that parties do not have to be lavish and expensive occasions, and it’s amazing what you can achieve by being clever and creative,” Carole wrote.
 
So, what tips does Carole have for parents?
 
—       Take the action outside (“Classic sports day games are great . . . there’s nothing better for burning off some excess energy”).

—       Don’t be afraid to get a *little* extravagant (“there are few bigger draws for children” than bouncy castles, she advises).

—       And don’t try to re-invent the wheel here (the cake should be the “centerpiece” of the party, she says).
 
Additionally, Carole suggests playing games of the more traditional variety (apple bobbing, kick the can, etc.), as well as delightfully titled British games like “What’s the Time, Mr. Wolf?” and “Grandmother’s Footsteps.”
 
“What in the world is ‘Grandmother’s Footsteps’?” we imagine Kate asking William, as they sip their morning tea. (“I have no earthly clue, but it sounds like a kind of scented candle, or the title of a horror movie,” William answers, not looking up from his paper.)
 
Per *People*, Carole will be continuing to contribute for *Little London*, as well as for *Baby London* magazine. 


[#gallery: /galleries/5544feb6db753b82389cc867]||||||
items.seoDescription: “We’ve always believed that parties do not have to be lavish and expensive occasions.”
